comment_text.mn125:1.1: This discourse uses the training of an elephant as an allegory for the Gradual Training. The Buddha contrasts the sensual lifestyle of Prince Jayasena, which clouds his vision of the truth, with the path of renunciation. Throughout, he lends support to the young novice Aciravata.
comment_text.mn125:2.2: Jayasena features in this discourse and the next. The commentary says he was Bimbisāra’s son. | Aciravata is otherwise unknown.
comment_text.mn125:3.2: Aciravati’s lack of confidence is understandable. Novices were under twenty, so here we have a rather intimidating situation where a Prince is questioning a teenager.
comment_text.mn125:7.2: Knowing his student lacks confidence, the Buddha has encouraging words for him, not letting him blame himself for Jayasena’s rejection.
comment_text.mn125:7.3: A parallel passage occurs at MN 125:7.3, where the phrases “dwells in the midst of sensual pleasures, enjoying them” are reversed. The sequence there makes better sense: it starts with where they are, then what they enjoy, and gradually moves up to being consumed and seeking more. I take this as the correct sense and translate both passages accordingly.
comment_text.mn125:9.1: This simile is contextual, as Rājagaha is indeed surrounded by mountains.
comment_text.mn125:9.2: For hatthavilaṅghaka (“lending a hand up”) see MN 31:9.7 = MN 128:14.7.
comment_text.mn125:13.1: The parallel at MA 198 is more straightforward, mentioning only purity of body, speech, and mind; undertaking mindfulness meditation; and entering the four absorptions.
comment_text.mn125:24.2: Editions vary and it is not easy to decide between them. MS and BJT editions have kāmūpasaṁhita (“connected with sensual pleasures”), while PTS has kāyūpasaṁhita (“connected with the body”), followed by “connected with feelings, mind, and principles” respectively. The Chinese parallel has “sensuality” in first place, abbreviates the next two, then “against the dhamma” for the final satipaṭṭhāna (MA 198 at T i 758b15). Sanskrit texts Pañcaviṁśatisāhasrikā Prajñāpāramitā and Pratyutpannabuddhasaṁmukhāvasthitasamādhi-sūtra have kāya. So the balance of the non-Pali texts supports the reading kāyūpasaṁhita. On the other hand, kāmūpasaṁhita is a common term, while kāyūpasaṁhita (etc.) appear only here; but the passage is passed over in the commentary and subcommentary, which suggests that they thought it was self-evident, making it unlikely that unique terms were used. Finally, the overall topic of the discourse is overcoming sensuality through meditation, and it would seem odd for the Buddha to be teaching specialized meditation instructions, found nowhere else, to a novice. Overall, then, I accept the reading kāmūpasaṁhita; see too the next note.
comment_text.mn125:25.1: The Pali version, in a unique presentation, has the four satipaṭṭhānas in place of the first absorption, which offers further light on the problem discussed in the previous note. The first absorption is characterized by seclusion from sensual pleasures, while vitakka is still present. Clearly one is not “thinking of sensual pleasures” at this point, so the reading kāmūpasaṁhita is unproblematic. But it is not clear that one is not having vitakka for the body (and feeling, mind, and principles). For example, in mindfulness of breathing one is applying the mind or “thinking of” the breath, in other words “thinking of the body”. Thus the reading kāyūpasaṁhita would be difficult to fully explain. Any conclusions on this passage, however, are tenuous, and it seems likely there has been some textual corruption. Indeed, the Chinese parallel here has all four absorptions as usual.
comment_text.mn125:32.4: The Buddha is giving gentle encouragement to Aciravata, reminding him that his junior status does not limit his spiritual growth.

root_text.mn125:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
root_text.mn125:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena aciravato samaṇuddeso araññakuṭikāyaṁ viharati.
root_text.mn125:2.2: Atha kho jayaseno rājakumāro jaṅghāvihāraṁ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno yena aciravato samaṇuddeso tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā aciravatena samaṇuddesena saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn125:2.3: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho jayaseno rājakumāro aciravataṁ samaṇuddesaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn125:2.5: ‘idha bhikkhu appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto phuseyya cittassa ekaggatan’”ti.
root_text.mn125:2.7: Idha bhikkhu appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto phuseyya cittassa ekaggatan”ti.
root_text.mn125:3.1: “Sādhu me bhavaṁ aggivessano yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ desetū”ti.
root_text.mn125:3.2: “Na kho te ahaṁ, rājakumāra, sakkomi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ desetuṁ.
root_text.mn125:3.3: Ahañca hi te, rājakumāra, yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ deseyyaṁ, tvañca me bhāsitassa atthaṁ na ājāneyyāsi; so mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā”ti.
root_text.mn125:4.1: “Desetu me bhavaṁ aggivessano yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ.
root_text.mn125:4.2: Appevanāmāhaṁ bhoto aggivessanassa bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājāneyyan”ti.
root_text.mn125:4.3: “Deseyyaṁ kho te ahaṁ, rājakumāra, yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ.
root_text.mn125:4.4: Sace me tvaṁ bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājāneyyāsi, iccetaṁ kusalaṁ;
root_text.mn125:4.5: no ce me tvaṁ bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājāneyyāsi, yathāsake tiṭṭheyyāsi, na maṁ tattha uttariṁ paṭipuccheyyāsī”ti.
root_text.mn125:4.6: “Desetu me bhavaṁ aggivessano yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ.
root_text.mn125:4.7: Sace ahaṁ bhoto aggivessanassa bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānissāmi, iccetaṁ kusalaṁ;
root_text.mn125:4.8: no ce ahaṁ bhoto aggivessanassa bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānissāmi, yathāsake tiṭṭhissāmi, nāhaṁ tattha bhavantaṁ aggivessanaṁ uttariṁ paṭipucchissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn125:5.1: Atha kho aciravato samaṇuddeso jayasenassa rājakumārassa yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ desesi.
root_text.mn125:5.2: Evaṁ vutte, jayaseno rājakumāro aciravataṁ samaṇuddesaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn125:5.3: “aṭṭhānametaṁ, bho aggivessana, anavakāso yaṁ bhikkhu appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto phuseyya cittassa ekaggatan”ti.
root_text.mn125:5.4: Atha kho jayaseno rājakumāro aciravatassa samaṇuddesassa aṭṭhānatañca anavakāsatañca pavedetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
root_text.mn125:6.1: Atha kho aciravato samaṇuddeso acirapakkante jayasene rājakumāre yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn125:6.2: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho aciravato samaṇuddeso yāvatako ahosi jayasenena rājakumārena saddhiṁ kathāsallāpo taṁ sabbaṁ bhagavato ārocesi.
root_text.mn125:7.1: Evaṁ vutte, bhagavā aciravataṁ samaṇuddesaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn125:7.3: Yaṁ taṁ nekkhammena ñātabbaṁ nekkhammena daṭṭhabbaṁ nekkhammena pattabbaṁ nekkhammena sacchikātabbaṁ taṁ vata jayaseno rājakumāro kāmamajjhe vasanto kāme paribhuñjanto kāmavitakkehi khajjamāno kāmapariḷāhena pariḍayhamāno kāmapariyesanāya ussuko ñassati vā dakkhati vā sacchi vā karissatī’ti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn125:8.1: Seyyathāpissu, aggivessana, dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā sudantā suvinītā, dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā adantā avinītā.
root_text.mn125:8.3: ye te dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā sudantā suvinītā, api nu te dantāva dantakāraṇaṁ gaccheyyuṁ, dantāva dantabhūmiṁ sampāpuṇeyyun”ti?
root_text.mn125:8.5: “Ye pana te dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā adantā avinītā, api nu te adantāva dantakāraṇaṁ gaccheyyuṁ, adantāva dantabhūmiṁ sampāpuṇeyyuṁ, seyyathāpi te dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā sudantā suvinītā”ti?
root_text.mn125:8.7: “Evameva kho, aggivessana, ‘yaṁ taṁ nekkhammena ñātabbaṁ nekkhammena daṭṭhabbaṁ nekkhammena pattabbaṁ nekkhammena sacchikātabbaṁ taṁ vata jayaseno rājakumāro kāmamajjhe vasanto kāme paribhuñjanto kāmavitakkehi khajjamāno kāmapariḷāhena pariḍayhamāno kāmapariyesanāya ussuko ñassati vā dakkhati vā sacchi vā karissatī’ti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn125:9.1: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre mahāpabbato.
root_text.mn125:9.2: Tamenaṁ dve sahāyakā tamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā nikkhamitvā hatthavilaṅghakena yena so pabbato tenupasaṅkameyyuṁ; upasaṅkamitvā eko sahāyako heṭṭhā pabbatapāde tiṭṭheyya, eko sahāyako uparipabbataṁ āroheyya.
root_text.mn125:9.3: Tamenaṁ heṭṭhā pabbatapāde ṭhito sahāyako uparipabbate ṭhitaṁ sahāyakaṁ evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn125:9.4: ‘yaṁ, samma, kiṁ tvaṁ passasi uparipabbate ṭhito’ti?
root_text.mn125:9.6: ‘passāmi kho ahaṁ, samma, uparipabbate ṭhito ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan’ti.
root_text.mn125:9.8: ‘aṭṭhānaṁ kho etaṁ, samma, anavakāso yaṁ tvaṁ uparipabbate ṭhito passeyyāsi ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan’ti.
root_text.mn125:9.9: Tamenaṁ uparipabbate ṭhito sahāyako heṭṭhimapabbatapādaṁ orohitvā taṁ sahāyakaṁ bāhāyaṁ gahetvā uparipabbataṁ āropetvā muhuttaṁ assāsetvā evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn125:9.10: ‘yaṁ, samma, kiṁ tvaṁ passasi uparipabbate ṭhito’ti?
root_text.mn125:9.12: ‘passāmi kho ahaṁ, samma, uparipabbate ṭhito ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan’ti.
root_text.mn125:9.14: ‘idāneva kho te, samma, bhāsitaṁ—mayaṁ evaṁ ājānāma—
root_text.mn125:9.15: aṭṭhānaṁ kho etaṁ samma, anavakāso yaṁ tvaṁ uparipabbate ṭhito passeyyāsi ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan’ti.
root_text.mn125:9.16: Idāneva ca pana te bhāsitaṁ mayaṁ evaṁ ājānāma:
root_text.mn125:9.17: ‘passāmi kho ahaṁ, samma, uparipabbate ṭhito ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan’ti.
root_text.mn125:9.19: ‘tathā hi panāhaṁ, samma, iminā mahatā pabbatena āvuto daṭṭheyyaṁ nāddasan’ti.
root_text.mn125:10.1: Ato mahantatarena, aggivessana, ‘avijjākhandhena jayaseno rājakumāro āvuto nivuto ophuṭo pariyonaddho.
root_text.mn125:10.2: So vata yaṁ taṁ nekkhammena ñātabbaṁ nekkhammena daṭṭhabbaṁ nekkhammena pattabbaṁ nekkhammena sacchikātabbaṁ taṁ vata jayaseno rājakumāro kāmamajjhe vasanto kāme paribhuñjanto kāmavitakkehi khajjamāno kāmapariḷāhena pariḍayhamāno kāmapariyesanāya ussuko ñassati vā dakkhati vā sacchi vā karissatī’ti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn125:11.1: Sace kho taṁ, aggivessana, jayasenassa rājakumārassa imā dve upamā paṭibhāyeyyuṁ, anacchariyaṁ te jayaseno rājakumāro pasīdeyya, pasanno ca te pasannākāraṁ kareyyā”ti.
root_text.mn125:11.2: “Kuto pana maṁ, bhante, jayasenassa rājakumārassa imā dve upamā paṭibhāyissanti anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā, seyyathāpi bhagavantan”ti?
root_text.mn125:12.1: “Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto nāgavanikaṁ āmanteti:
root_text.mn125:12.2: ‘ehi tvaṁ, samma nāgavanika, rañño nāgaṁ abhiruhitvā nāgavanaṁ pavisitvā āraññakaṁ nāgaṁ atipassitvā rañño nāgassa gīvāyaṁ upanibandhāhī’ti.
root_text.mn125:12.3: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, aggivessana, nāgavaniko rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa paṭissutvā rañño nāgaṁ abhiruhitvā nāgavanaṁ pavisitvā āraññakaṁ nāgaṁ atipassitvā rañño nāgassa gīvāyaṁ upanibandhati.
root_text.mn125:12.5: Ettāvatā kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo abbhokāsaṁ gato hoti.
root_text.mn125:12.6: Etthagedhā hi, aggivessana, āraññakā nāgā yadidaṁ—nāgavanaṁ.
root_text.mn125:12.7: Tamenaṁ nāgavaniko rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa ārocesi:
root_text.mn125:12.9: Atha kho aggivessana, tamenaṁ rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto hatthidamakaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn125:12.10: ‘ehi tvaṁ, samma hatthidamaka, āraññakaṁ nāgaṁ damayāhi āraññakānañceva sīlānaṁ abhinimmadanāya āraññakānañceva sarasaṅkappānaṁ abhinimmadanāya āraññakānañceva darathakilamathapariḷāhānaṁ abhinimmadanāya gāmante abhiramāpanāya manussakantesu sīlesu samādapanāyā’ti.
root_text.mn125:12.11: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, aggivessana, hatthidamako rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa paṭissutvā mahantaṁ thambhaṁ pathaviyaṁ nikhaṇitvā āraññakassa nāgassa gīvāyaṁ upanibandhati āraññakānañceva sīlānaṁ abhinimmadanāya āraññakānañceva sarasaṅkappānaṁ abhinimmadanāya āraññakānañceva darathakilamathapariḷāhānaṁ abhinimmadanāya gāmante abhiramāpanāya manussakantesu sīlesu samādapanāya.
root_text.mn125:12.12: Tamenaṁ hatthidamako yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpāhi vācāhi samudācarati.
root_text.mn125:12.13: Yato kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo hatthidamakassa yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpāhi vācāhi samudācariyamāno sussūsati, sotaṁ odahati, aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhāpeti;
root_text.mn125:12.15: Yato kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo hatthidamakassa tiṇaghāsodakaṁ paṭiggaṇhāti, tatra hatthidamakassa evaṁ hoti:
root_text.mn125:12.19: Yato kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo hatthidamakassa ādānanikkhepe vacanakaro hoti ovādappaṭikaro, tamenaṁ hatthidamako uttari kāraṇaṁ kāreti:
root_text.mn125:12.21: Yato kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo hatthidamakassa abhikkamapaṭikkamavacanakaro hoti ovādappaṭikaro, tamenaṁ hatthidamako uttari kāraṇaṁ kāreti:
root_text.mn125:12.23: Yato kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo hatthidamakassa uṭṭhānanisajjāya vacanakaro hoti ovādappaṭikaro, tamenaṁ hatthidamako uttari āneñjaṁ nāma kāraṇaṁ kāreti, mahantassa phalakaṁ soṇḍāya upanibandhati, tomarahattho ca puriso uparigīvāya nisinno hoti, samantato ca tomarahatthā purisā parivāretvā ṭhitā honti, hatthidamako ca dīghatomarayaṭṭhiṁ gahetvā purato ṭhito hoti.
root_text.mn125:12.24: So āneñjaṁ kāraṇaṁ kāriyamāno neva purime pāde copeti na pacchime pāde copeti, na purimakāyaṁ copeti na pacchimakāyaṁ copeti, na sīsaṁ copeti, na kaṇṇe copeti, na dante copeti, na naṅguṭṭhaṁ copeti, na soṇḍaṁ copeti.
root_text.mn125:12.25: So hoti āraññako nāgo khamo sattippahārānaṁ asippahārānaṁ usuppahārānaṁ sarapattappahārānaṁ bheripaṇavavaṁsasaṅkhaḍiṇḍimaninnādasaddānaṁ sabbavaṅkadosanihitaninnītakasāvo rājāraho rājabhoggo rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
root_text.mn125:13.1: Evameva kho, aggivessana, idha tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
root_text.mn125:13.2: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
root_text.mn125:13.3: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
root_text.mn125:14.1: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
root_text.mn125:14.2: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
root_text.mn125:14.3: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn125:14.5: Nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
root_text.mn125:14.6: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn125:14.7: So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.mn125:14.8: Ettāvatā kho, aggivessana, ariyasāvako abbhokāsagato hoti.
root_text.mn125:14.9: Etthagedhā hi, aggivessana, devamanussā yadidaṁ—pañca kāmaguṇā.
root_text.mn125:15.2: ‘ehi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, sīlavā hohi, pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharāhi ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhassu sikkhāpadesū’ti.
root_text.mn125:16.1: Yato kho, aggivessana, ariyasāvako sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, tamenaṁ tathāgato uttariṁ vineti:
root_text.mn125:16.2: ‘ehi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, indriyesu guttadvāro hohi, cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā mā nimittaggāhī …pe…
root_text.mn125:22.1: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
root_text.mn125:22.2: kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
root_text.mn125:23.3: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
root_text.mn125:23.4: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, hatthidamako mahantaṁ thambhaṁ pathaviyaṁ nikhaṇitvā āraññakassa nāgassa gīvāyaṁ upanibandhati āraññakānañceva sīlānaṁ abhinimmadanāya āraññakānañceva sarasaṅkappānaṁ abhinimmadanāya āraññakānañceva darathakilamathapariḷāhānaṁ abhinimmadanāya gāmante abhiramāpanāya manussakantesu sīlesu samādapanāya;
root_text.mn125:23.5: evameva kho, aggivessana, ariyasāvakassa ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā cetaso upanibandhanā honti gehasitānañceva sīlānaṁ abhinimmadanāya gehasitānañceva sarasaṅkappānaṁ abhinimmadanāya gehasitānañceva darathakilamathapariḷāhānaṁ abhinimmadanāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya.
root_text.mn125:24.2: ‘ehi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, kāye kāyānupassī viharāhi, mā ca kāmūpasaṁhitaṁ vitakkaṁ vitakkesi.
root_text.mn125:24.5: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāhi, mā ca kāmūpasaṁhitaṁ vitakkaṁ vitakkesī’ti.
root_text.mn125:25.1: So vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
root_text.mn125:26.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn125:26.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn125:27-28.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn125:27-28.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
root_text.mn125:29.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn125:29.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti;
root_text.mn125:29.3: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn125:29.4: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
root_text.mn125:29.6: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn125:30.1: So hoti bhikkhu khamo sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ duruttānaṁ durāgatānaṁ vacanapathānaṁ, uppannānaṁ sārīrikānaṁ vedanānaṁ dukkhānaṁ tibbānaṁ kharānaṁ kaṭukānaṁ asātānaṁ amanāpānaṁ pāṇaharānaṁ adhivāsakajātiko hoti
root_text.mn125:30.2: sabbarāgadosamohanihitaninnītakasāvo āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassa.
root_text.mn125:31.1: Mahallako cepi, aggivessana, rañño nāgo adanto avinīto kālaṁ karoti, ‘adantamaraṇaṁ mahallako rañño nāgo kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn125:31.3: Daharo cepi, aggivessana, rañño nāgo adanto avinīto kālaṁ karoti, ‘adantamaraṇaṁ daharo rañño nāgo kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn125:31.4: evameva kho, aggivessana, thero cepi bhikkhu akhīṇāsavo kālaṁ karoti, ‘adantamaraṇaṁ thero bhikkhu kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn125:31.6: Navo cepi, aggivessana, bhikkhu akhīṇāsavo kālaṁ karoti, ‘adantamaraṇaṁ navo bhikkhu kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
root_text.mn125:32.1: Mahallako cepi, aggivessana, rañño nāgo sudanto suvinīto kālaṁ karoti, ‘dantamaraṇaṁ mahallako rañño nāgo kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn125:32.3: daharo cepi, aggivessana, rañño nāgo sudanto suvinīto kālaṁ karoti, ‘dantamaraṇaṁ daharo rañño nāgo kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn125:32.4: evameva kho, aggivessana, thero cepi bhikkhu khīṇāsavo kālaṁ karoti, ‘dantamaraṇaṁ thero bhikkhu kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn125:32.6: Navo cepi, aggivessana, bhikkhu khīṇāsavo kālaṁ karoti, ‘dantamaraṇaṁ navo bhikkhu kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchatī”ti.
root_text.mn125:32.8: Attamano aciravato samaṇuddeso bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn125:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
translation_text.mn125:2.1: Now at that time the novice Aciravata was staying in a wilderness hut.
translation_text.mn125:2.2: Then as Prince Jayasena was going for a walk he approached Aciravata, and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn125:2.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Aciravata,
translation_text.mn125:2.5: a mendicant who meditates diligently, keenly, and resolutely can experience unification of mind.”
translation_text.mn125:2.6: “That’s so true, Prince! That’s so true!
translation_text.mn125:2.7: A mendicant who meditates diligently, keenly, and resolutely can experience unification of mind.”
translation_text.mn125:3.1: “Worthy Aggivessana, please teach me the Dhamma as you have learned and memorized it.”
translation_text.mn125:3.2: “I’m not competent to do so, Prince.
translation_text.mn125:3.3: For if I were to teach you the Dhamma as I have learned and memorized it, you might not understand the meaning, which would be wearying and troublesome for me.”
translation_text.mn125:4.1: “Worthy Aggivessana, please teach me the Dhamma as you have learned and memorized it.
translation_text.mn125:4.2: Hopefully I will understand the meaning of what you say.”
translation_text.mn125:4.4: If you understand the meaning of what I say, that’s good.
translation_text.mn125:4.5: If not, then leave each to his own, and do not question me about it further.”
translation_text.mn125:4.6: “Worthy Aggivessana, please teach me the Dhamma as you have learned and memorized it.
translation_text.mn125:4.7: If I understand the meaning of what you say, that’s good.
translation_text.mn125:4.8: If not, then I will leave each to his own, and not question you about it further.”
translation_text.mn125:5.1: Then the novice Aciravata taught Prince Jayasena the Dhamma as he had learned and memorized it.
translation_text.mn125:5.2: When he had spoken, Jayasena said to him,
translation_text.mn125:5.3: “It is impossible, worthy Aggivessana, it cannot happen that a mendicant who meditates diligently, keenly, and resolutely can experience unification of mind.”
translation_text.mn125:5.4: Having declared that this was impossible, Jayasena got up from his seat and left.
translation_text.mn125:6.1: Not long after he had left, Aciravata went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
translation_text.mn125:6.2: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.
translation_text.mn125:7.1: When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn125:7.2: “How could it possibly be otherwise, Aggivessana?
translation_text.mn125:7.3: Prince Jayasena dwells in the midst of sensual pleasures, enjoying them, consumed by thoughts of them, burning with fever for them, and eagerly seeking more. It’s simply impossible for him to know or see or realize what can only be known, seen, and realized by renunciation.
translation_text.mn125:8.1: Suppose there was a pair of elephants or horse or oxen in training who were well tamed and well trained. And there was a pair who were not tamed or trained.
translation_text.mn125:8.3: Wouldn’t the pair that was well tamed and well trained perform the tasks of the tamed and reach the level of the tamed?”
translation_text.mn125:8.5: “But would the pair that was not tamed and trained perform the tasks of the tamed and reach the level of the tamed, just like the tamed pair?”
translation_text.mn125:8.7: “In the same way, Prince Jayasena dwells in the midst of sensual pleasures, enjoying them, consumed by thoughts of them, burning with fever for them, and eagerly seeking more. It’s simply impossible for him to know or see or realize what can only be known, seen, and realized by renunciation.
translation_text.mn125:9.1: Suppose there was a big mountain not far from a town or village.
translation_text.mn125:9.2: And two friends set out from that village or town, lending each other a hand up to the mountain. Once there, one friend would remain at the foot of the mountain, while the other would climb to the peak.
translation_text.mn125:9.3: The one standing at the foot would say to the one at the peak,
translation_text.mn125:9.4: ‘My friend, what do you see, standing there at the peak?’
translation_text.mn125:9.6: ‘Standing at the peak, I see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds!’
translation_text.mn125:9.8: ‘It’s impossible, it cannot happen that, standing at the peak, you can see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds.’
translation_text.mn125:9.9: So their friend would come down from the peak, take their friend by the arm, and make them climb to the peak. After giving them a while to catch their breath, they’d say,
translation_text.mn125:9.10: ‘My friend, what do you see, standing here at the peak?’
translation_text.mn125:9.12: ‘Standing at the peak, I see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds!’
translation_text.mn125:9.14: ‘Just now I understood you to say:
translation_text.mn125:9.15: “It’s impossible, it cannot happen that, standing at the peak, you can see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds.”
translation_text.mn125:9.17: “Standing at the peak, I see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds!”’
translation_text.mn125:9.19: ‘But my friend, it was because I was obstructed by this big mountain that I didn’t see what could be seen.’
translation_text.mn125:10.1: But bigger than that is the mass of ignorance by which Prince Jayasena is veiled, shrouded, covered, and engulfed.
translation_text.mn125:10.2: Prince Jayasena dwells in the midst of sensual pleasures, enjoying them, consumed by thoughts of them, burning with fever for them, and eagerly seeking more. It is quite impossible for him to know or see or realize what can only be known, seen, and realized by renunciation.
translation_text.mn125:11.1: It would be no wonder if, had these two similes occurred to you, Prince Jayasena would have gained confidence in you and shown his confidence.”
translation_text.mn125:11.2: “But sir, how could these two similes have occurred to me as they did to the Buddha, since they were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past?”
translation_text.mn125:12.1: “Suppose, Aggivessana, an anointed aristocratic king was to address his elephant tracker,
translation_text.mn125:12.2: ‘Please, my good elephant tracker, mount the royal bull elephant and enter the elephant wood. When you see a wild bull elephant, tether it by the neck to the royal elephant.’
translation_text.mn125:12.3: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the elephant tracker, and did as he was asked.
translation_text.mn125:12.4: The royal elephant leads the wild elephant out into the open;
translation_text.mn125:12.5: and it’s only then that it comes out into the open,
translation_text.mn125:12.6: for a wild bull elephant clings to the elephant wood.
translation_text.mn125:12.7: The elephant tracker informs the king,
translation_text.mn125:12.8: ‘Sire, the wild elephant has come out into the open.’
translation_text.mn125:12.9: Then the king addresses his elephant trainer,
translation_text.mn125:12.10: ‘Please, my good elephant trainer, tame the wild bull elephant. Subdue its wild behaviors, its wild memories and thoughts, and its wild stress, weariness, and fever. Make it happy to be within a village, and instill behaviors congenial to humans.’
translation_text.mn125:12.11: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the elephant trainer. He dug a large post into the earth and tethered the elephant to it by the neck, so as to subdue its wild behaviors, its wild memories and thoughts, and its wild stress, weariness, and fever, and to make it happy to be within a village, and instill behaviors congenial to humans.
translation_text.mn125:12.12: He spoke in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
translation_text.mn125:12.13: Spoken to in such a way by the elephant trainer, the wild elephant wanted to listen. It actively listened and tried to understand.
translation_text.mn125:12.14: So the elephant trainer rewards it with grass, fodder, and water.
translation_text.mn125:12.15: When the wild elephant accepts the grass, fodder, and water, the trainer knows,
translation_text.mn125:12.17: He sets it a further task:
translation_text.mn125:12.18: ‘Pick it up, worthy sir! Put it down, worthy sir!’
translation_text.mn125:12.19: When the wild elephant picks up and puts down when the trainer says, following instructions, the trainer sets it a further task:
translation_text.mn125:12.21: When the wild elephant goes forward and back when the trainer says, following instructions, the trainer sets it a further task:
translation_text.mn125:12.23: When the wild elephant stands and sits when the trainer says, following instructions, the trainer sets the task called imperturbability. He fastens a large plank to its trunk; a lancer sits on its neck; other lancers surround it on all sides; and the trainer himself stands in front with a long lance.
translation_text.mn125:12.24: While practicing this task, it doesn’t budge its fore-feet or hind-feet, its fore-quarters or hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, tail, or trunk.
translation_text.mn125:12.25: The wild bull elephant endures being struck by spears, swords, arrows, and axes; it endures the thunder of the drums, kettledrums, horns, and tom-toms. Rid of all crooks and flaws, and purged of defects, it is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and reckoned a factor of kingship.
translation_text.mn125:13.1: In the same way, Aggivessana, a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
translation_text.mn125:13.2: He realizes with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn125:13.3: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.mn125:14.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
translation_text.mn125:14.2: They gain faith in the Realized One
translation_text.mn125:14.4: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
translation_text.mn125:14.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.mn125:14.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.mn125:14.7: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn125:14.8: And it’s only then that a noble disciple comes out into the open,
translation_text.mn125:14.9: for gods and humans cling to the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn125:15.1: The Realized One guides them further:
translation_text.mn125:15.2: ‘Come, mendicant, be ethical and restrained in the monastic code, conducting yourself well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.’
translation_text.mn125:16.1: When they have ethical conduct, the Realized One guides them further:
translation_text.mn125:16.2: ‘Come, mendicant, guard your sense doors. When you see a sight with your eyes, don’t get caught up in the features and details. …
translation_text.mn125:17-21.1: (Tell in full as in MN 107, the Discourse with Moggallāna the Accountant.)
translation_text.mn125:22.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.mn125:22.2: Then they meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn125:23.1: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
translation_text.mn125:23.3: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
translation_text.mn125:23.4: It’s like when the elephant trainer dug a large post into the earth and tethered the elephant to it by the neck, so as to subdue its wild behaviors, its wild memories and thoughts, and its wild stress, weariness, and fever, and to make it happy to be within a village, and instill behaviors congenial to humans.
translation_text.mn125:23.5: In the same way, a noble disciple has these four kinds of mindfulness meditation as tethers for the mind so as to subdue behaviors tied to domestic life, memories and thoughts tied to domestic life, stress, weariness, and fever tied to domestic life, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.
translation_text.mn125:24.1: The Realized One guides them further:
translation_text.mn125:24.2: ‘Come, mendicant, meditate observing an aspect of the body, but don’t think thoughts connected with sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn125:24.3: Meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
translation_text.mn125:24.5: principles, but don’t think thoughts connected with sensual pleasures.’
translation_text.mn125:25.1: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …
translation_text.mn125:26.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn125:26.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn125:27-28.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn125:27-28.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn125:29.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn125:29.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
translation_text.mn125:29.3: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
translation_text.mn125:29.4: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn125:29.5: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn125:29.6: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn125:30.1: Such a mendicant endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism; and puts up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
translation_text.mn125:30.2: Rid of all greed, hate, and delusion, and purged of defects, they are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.
translation_text.mn125:31.1: If a royal bull elephant—whether elderly, middle aged, or youthful—passes away untamed and untrained, they’re reckoned a royal bull elephant who passed away untamed.
translation_text.mn125:31.4: In the same way, if a mendicant—whether senior, middle, or junior—passes away without having ended the defilements, they’re reckoned a mendicant who passed away untamed.
translation_text.mn125:32.1: If a royal bull elephant—whether elderly, middle aged, or youthful—passes away tamed and trained, they’re reckoned a royal bull elephant who passed away tamed.
translation_text.mn125:32.4: In the same way, if a mendicant—whether senior, middle, or junior—passes away having ended the defilements, they’re reckoned a mendicant who passed away tamed.”
translation_text.mn125:32.7: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn125:32.8: Satisfied, the novice Aciravata approved what the Buddha said.
